name: Leodamas of Thasos
content:
Leodamas of Thasos (Greek: Λεωδάμας ὁ Θάσιος, c. 380 BC) was a Greek mathematician and a contemporary of Plato, about whom little is known.
 There are two references to Leodamas in Proclus's Commentary on Euclid:[1]
 "At this time [Plato's time] also lived Leodamas of Thasos, Archytas of Tarentum, and Theaetetus of Athens, by whom the
     theorems [of geometry] were increased in number and brought into a more scientific arrangement.  Younger than Leodamas was
 Neoclides and his pupil Leon, who added many discoveries." "Plato, it is said, taught this method [analysis] to Leodamas, who is also reported to have made many discoveries in geometry by
    means of it." and one in Diogenes Laërtius' Lives and Opinions of Eminent Philosophers, Book 3 (Plato):
 "He [Plato] was the first to explain to Leodamas of Thasos the
    method of solving problems by analysis."
